name: Typing series #5 --> the insert key and moving cursor
description: First and foremost, thank you to vintrom for the idea. I may have changed it a little (sorry about that!), but I think that this is good. Alright, back to the puzzle! ___ You are given a `string` of lowercase letters and spaces that you need to type out. However, there are some functions in the string that you have to process. The function this time is: the `ins` key. When pressed, it replaces text at the cursor by what is typed next. Examples: ``` abcd[ins 1]yyy -> ayyy Walkthrough: | -> cursor a| ab| abc| abcd| (cursor goes to index one, press ins) a|bcd ay|cd (ins replacement mode) ayy|d ayyy| (done) mgk the goat[ins 0]emi[ins]nem -> eminem the goat Walkthrough: ... ... mgk the goat| (cursor goes to index zero, press ins) |mgk the goat e|gk the goat em|k the goat emi| the goat (turn off ins) emin| the goat emine| the goat eminem| the goat (done) [ins]rubiks[ins] cure[ins -3]b -> rubiks cube Walkthrough: ins turned on r| ru| ... ... rubiks| [ins] pressed, do not move cursor rubiks cur| rubiks cure| (cursor index -3, right behind r) rubiks cu|re rubiks cub|e (done) ``` But what if you need to move the cursor but not press ins? Let's add a new function `[n]`. It moves the cursor to `index n` without pressing `ins`. (n can be negative too) ``` Examples: square of two[6] root -> squre root of two Walkthrough: s| sq| ... ... square of two| (go to index 6) square| of two ... ... square root of two (done) okay[ins 3][2][ins][ins 0]not okay -> not okay Walkthrough: ... ... okay| oka|y (ins on) ok|ay (index 2) ok|ay (ins off) |okay (ins 0) (on) ... ... not okay (done) ``` ___ Notes: - In the functions [ins n] and [n], n will never be empty and (-len(s)-1 <= n <= len(s)). - `[ins]` is a toggle (just like the key on your keyboard). ``` Take a look at the string: aa[n]x. if n == -1: current step: aa| cursor index: -1 aa[ins -1]x -> aax if n == -2: current step: a|a cursor index: -2 aa[ins -2]x -> axa if n == -3: current step: |aa cursor index: -3 aa[ins -3]x -> xaa ``` - If something like this occurs: ``` [ins n]...text...[ins n] ins toggles on, and then off. Examples: abcd[ins 0]wxyz[ins 0]pqrs -> pqrswxyz [ins]hello world[-6][ins]world -> hello worldworld ``` If it gets too confusing, you can always try typing it out yourself on a text editor. Good luck! ______ Check out the rest of the kata in this series!
